title: "The Power of Fascination: Combining Gaze, Gesture, and Voice"
first_phrase: In the preceding text, the author delves into the concept of fascination, exploring its power and the various means by which it can be employed. Continuing on this theme, the author cites several historical figures such as S. Thomas, Aristotle, and Alexander, and their thoughts on how the power of fascination can be achieved through various methods – from using gestures and touch to the mere sound of a person's voice. The author also notes how different schools, including the Arab and Jewish cultures, have explored the concept of fascination. In the following 200 tokens, the author further explores the notion of fascination and its deeper relationship with the universe.
content: Se trata de operaciones de reequilibrio, y para hacer aquello ahora también importante es que el ánimo del operador se alinee a la armonía del universo[30]. Además que con los gestos, por lo que añade un encanto adicional se combina la voz. Aristóteles habla de él como la causa de la fascinación, y dice que el mero sonido de la voz de un seductor tiene este poder, independientemente de su voluntad positiva o negativa, así como las palabras específicas. Alexander llama a la Afrodisiense encanto "envenenadores", infectar a sus víctimas, como mirándolo a él, "Carmine alargada", es decir "con una canción o una cadencia medida." Muchos conceptos de las escuelas existentes en secreto o esotérico contienen en su interior relaciones con lo que digo ahora. Los árabes hablaban de una sustancia invisible que fue enviada sobre la persona fascinada.[31]. Entre los judíos hay claras referencias a la fascinación. En el Talmud, el verbo "szekar" significa "encanto, con la mirada."
last_phrase: In conclusion, throughout history, various cultures and traditions have recognized the power of fascination and its effects on individuals. The idea that one's mood should align with the harmony of the universe to achieve a re-balancing of energies is also essential. The practical application of these concepts can be seen in Mesmer's techniques, such as staring intensely at the subject before working with touch, resulting in instant healing. Ultimately, the power of fascination remains a fascinating area of study and practice that is still relevant today.
